variant.question: Which statement about the Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse is correct?

options.text: This pulse is transmitted by the transponder as a result of the pilot pushing the IDENT-button.
This pulse is transmitted automatically every time the transponder responds to a mode A interrogation.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator if it is suspected that responses are received from aircraft which are located in the direction of the side lobes of the interrogator antenna.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator in order to request for identification of a certain aircraft.

variant.question: Which statement about the Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse is correct?

options.text: This pulse is transmitted by the transponder as a result of the pilot pushing the IDENT button.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator in order to request for identification of a certain aircraft.
This pulse is transmitted automatically every time the transponder responds to a mode A interrogation.
This pulse is transmitted by the SSR-interrogator if it is suspected that responses are received from aircraft which are located in the direction of the side lobes of the interrogator antenna.

variant.question: Which statement with respect to interrogation modes is correct?

options.text: Mode S Broadcast will transmit information to all mode S transponders.
Mode S Only all-call will trigger transponder replies of all mode A/C/S transponders.
Intermode A/C/S all call and Intermode A/C only all call, differ in the pulse spacing used between the P1 and P3 pulse.
Mode S Selective will trigger replies of all mode S transponders. Mode A/C transponders are suppressed.

variant.question: Which one of the following switch positions should be used when selecting a code on the transponder?

options.text: STBY (Standby).
IDENT (Identification).
OFF
NORMAL

variant.question: A transponder set to Mode A/C is responding to an intermode radar that is capable of interrogating modes A, C and S. What does the operating mode of the transponder depend on?

options.text: The time between paired interrogation pulses.
The repetition frequency of pulse pairs in the interrogation signal.
The carrier wave frequency of the interrogation signal.
The length of the interrogation pulse.

variant.question: A Mode C-transponder is able to report the pressure altitude in:

options.text: 100 ft increments.
25 ft increments.
100 m increments.
50 m increments.

variant.question: With reference to Mode S transponders, which statement is correct? The reported altitude data...

options.text: could be accurate to 25 ft resolution but it is dependent on the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.
must be accurate to 25 ft resolution and be dependent on the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.
must be accurate to 100 ft resolution and be independent of the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.
could be accurate to 25 ft resolution and is independent of the altitude sensor systems on board the aircraft.

variant.question: A mode A/C transponder receives a P2 pulse from which the amplitude is larger than that of the P1 and P3 pulse. What is the matter?

options.text: The transponder is located in the direction of one of the side lobes of the interrogator antenna.
The interrogation is only meant for mode S transponders.
The transponder is beyond the usable range of the SSR ground station.
The transponder is located in the direction of the main lobe of the interrogator antenna.

variant.question: With mode-S each aircraft can be uniquely interrogated and identified by using the...

options.text: 24-bits address code, giving more than 16 million possible codes.
twelve-pulse train, giving 212 possible codes.
Special Position Identification (SPI) pulse.
long (30.25 msec) P3 pulse.

variant.question: A mode S transponder will respond to...

options.text: SSR and TCAS
TCAS and primary radar
TCAS and ADS-B
SSR and ADS-B
